column2: Surface map at 12 PM CST on March 18, 1925 (Maddox et al, 2013)

column2: Surface map at 4 PM CST on March 18, 1925 (Maddox et al, 2013)
column5: Surface map at 7 PM CST on March 18, 1925 (Maddox et al, 2013)

column1: Map of damage points on March 18, 1925 from research published by Robert H. Johns et al in 2013.
Damage in Annapolis MO, where most of the town was damaged or destroyed. (Credit: Iron County Historical Society)
column2: Damage to the local lead mines in Leadanna MO. (Credit: Iron County Historical Society)
column5: Home west of Sedgewickville MO in Bollinger County completely destroyed. (Credit: Missouri Digital Archives)
column6: Destruction in Biehle MO with dozens of homes destroyed. (Credit: Missouri Digital Archives)

column1: Residence in Biehle MO completely destroyed by the tornado. (Credit: Missouri Digital Archives)
column2: Damage to a well-built home northeast of Frohna MO. (Credit: Missouri Digital Archives)
column5: Surveyors examining a 1X5 inch board driven through a 2X6 plank somewhere along the path of the tornado. (Credit: NOAA/NWS archives)
column6: More than a dozen boxcars thrown and a section of train tracks ripped from the ground in western Gorham IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Devastation in Gorham IL where 35 residents were killed, and every structure was damaged or destroyed. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: More damage along the Missouri Pacific Railway in Gorham IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Destruction in the area of the Post Office in downtown Gorham IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: View of Murphysboro IL before the tornado facing northwest from atop the Brown Shoe Company water tower. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Another view of Murphysboro IL before the tornado but facing northeast instead. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: Aerial view of Murphysboro IL after the tornado as hundreds of homes and business were demolished. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Damage at the corner of 17th and Walnut Streets in downtown Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Thirteen people perished when the Blue Front Hotel in Murphysboro IL caught fire in the hours following the tornado. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Originally a 3-story building, Werner's Drug Store in Murphysboro IL was reduced to only 2 stories by the tornado. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: A view of damage to the business district of Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: First Baptist Church in Murphysboro IL destroyed by the tornado. A funeral service was ongoing when the tornado hit. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: The Reliance Mill on N 17th St in Murphysboro IL was demolished by the tornado and was never rebuilt. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Damage to the Brown Shoe Company in Murphysboro IL (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: Destruction to the M&O Railroad shops in Murphysboro IL. The roof caved in on 500 workers, killing 35 and injuring hundreds. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Aerial view of the devastation at the Mobile & Ohio railyards in Murphysboro IL (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Damage to the Murphysboro Township High School. Three students died when the central part of the school collapsed. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: The tornado completely destroyed Logan School in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: More damage in Murphysboro IL. In the background are ruins of Logan School, where 9 children were killed. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Another 17 children lost their lives at Longfellow School in Murphysboro IL as the building partially collapsed. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: An aerial view of the destruction around the high school in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Tents served as temporary shelter after the storm. This view is from 17th and Victory Streets in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: Looking south from the intersection of 17th and Hortense Streets in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: More damage in Murphysboro IL. This was the scene at the intersection of Gartside and 14th Streets. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Typical scene in the residential district of Murphysboro IL where over 150 city blocks were destroyed by the tornado. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Homes in Murphysboro IL splintered to pieces by the tornado, which left half of the city's population homeless. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: This scene at North 9th Street Park in Murphysboro IL was common as tent cities sprung up to house the homeless. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: This photograph of general damage depicts the magnitude of the devastation in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Another look at the destruction left behind in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Another aerial view of the destruction caused by the tornado in Murphysboro IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: Front page of the Chicago Herald and Examiner on March 20, 1925 with the destruction in Murphysboro IL front page. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Fires in Murphysboro IL after the tornado. Overall, 234 people lost their lives with hundreds more seriously injured. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: A look at the devastation just west of the town of De Soto IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: Aerial view of the destruction caused by the tornado in De Soto IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: A look at the aftermath of the tornado in De Soto IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Damage to the business district in the town of De Soto IL after the tornado. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Another look at tornado damage in the business district of De Soto IL. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)

column1: A view of the De Soto IL Elementary School before the tornado struck. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column2: The tornado caused the entire second story of the De Soto IL school to collapse. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column5: Another view of the De Soto IL school, where 33 children lost their lives. (Credit: Jackson County Historical Society)
column6: Damage to a bridge between Royalton and Colp IL as the tornado plowed through the Hurst-Bush area of Williamson County. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)

column1: School left in ruins in the rural area of Plumfield, just west of West Frankfort IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column2: The tornado damaged this home to the west of West Frankfort IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column5: This is an aerial view of the tornado damage to homes on the west side of West Frankfort IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column6: Complete devastation to the Orient No. 2 mine and surrounding homes on the northwest side of West Frankfort IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)

column1: Another aerial view of the destruction on the northwest side of West Frankfort IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column2: Coal cars blown off their tracks on the northwest side of West Frankfort IL, where the tornado claimed 132 lives. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column5: Another home completely demolished to the northeast of West Frankfort as the tornado approached Parrish IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column6: One of many homes destroyed by the tornado in rural Hamilton County IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)

column1: Remains of a home near Olga in southern Hamilton County IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column2: Complete destruction of Trousdale School just southeast of Enfield IL. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column5: Devastation at Newman School in rural White County IL, where all the school children miraculously survived. (Credit: Stormstalker.wordpress.com)
column6: One of several homes demolished southwest of Griffin IN. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)

column1: Complete devastation in Griffin IN, where the entire town was wiped off the map. (Credit: NOAA/NWS archives)
column2: Another view of Griffin IN, where dozens were killed and a couple hundred were injured. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column5: Similar to other towns in the tornado's path, tents sprung up to house the homeless in Griffin IN. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column6: A look at the destruction in the business district of Griffin IN. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)

column1: A view of more devastation in Griffin IN, where the entire town was destroyed. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column2: The Griffin School in Griffin IN was destroyed by the tornado. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column5: A distant view of Griffin School with remnants of other buildings in Griffin IN splintered in the foreground. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column6: Another building in Griffin IN completely demolished by the tornado. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)

column1: Brick buildings leveled by the tornado on the east side of Griffin IN. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column2: More structural damage in the town of Griffin IN. (Credit: Posey County Historical Society)
column5: Locomotive rolled by the tornado near the community of Princeton IN. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column6: Destruction to homes in the Baldwin Heights area of Princeton IN. (Credit: Princeton Public Library)

column1: More homes destroyed in the Baldwin Heights area of Princeton IN. (Credit: Princeton Public Library)
column2: Homes in the McCaw subdivision demolished in Princeton IN. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column5: More destruction in the McCaw subdivision in Princeton IN, where 45 people perished in the community. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column6: Damage to the Baldwin Heights School in Princeton IN. (Credit: Princeton Public Library)

column1: A look at the Baldwin Heights School in Princeton IN before and after the tornado struck. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column2: A family sits on the foundation of a home destroyed by the tornado in Princeton IN. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column5: Damage to the H.J. Heinz factory, one of the largest employers in Princeton IN at the time. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column6: Another look at the heavily damaged H.J. Heinz factory in Princeton IN. (Credit: Princeton Public Library)

column1: Front page of the Princeton Clarion-News on March 19, 1925. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column2: Tornado damage to the Southern Railway Shops in Princeton IN. (Credit: Princeton Public Library)
column5: Damage to homes near the Southern Railway shops in Princton IN (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)
column6: Rubble from a structure near the Heinz plant in Princeton IN destroyed by the tornado. (Credit: Indiana State Library Archives)

column1: Simulation of how the Storm Prediction Center's Day 1 Outlook may have looked on March 18, 1925 (Dan McCarthy, former WCM at SPC)
column2: Simulation of how a Tornado Watch issued by SPC may have looked on March 18, 1925 (Dan McCarthy, former WCM at SPC)
